definition: The ongoing process of strategically identifying, attracting, and hiring people with skills that match the organization’s long-term needs.
example: Our Talent acquisition team builds relationships with niche communities long before a vacancy appears.

definition: The set of activities used to shape how current and potential employees perceive an organization as a place to work.
example: Improving our Employer branding reduced the number of candidates who declined offers at the last minute.

definition: The unique mix of benefits, culture, and career opportunities that an organization promises in exchange for an employee’s skills and commitment.
example: We rewrote the Employer value proposition to emphasize learning opportunities and flexible work.

definition: A structured process for forecasting future talent needs and aligning staffing levels with business objectives.
example: Through Workforce planning, HR identified critical roles that need successors in the next three years.

definition: The process of determining the number and type of positions an organization requires over a specific time horizon.
example: Finance and HR collaborate on Headcount planning during the annual budget cycle.

definition: A pool of pre-qualified and engaged candidates who can fill current and future vacancies with minimal delay.
example: Maintaining a strong Talent pipeline helped us replace a departing director within a few weeks.

definition: A curated group of people with relevant skills who have shown interest in working for the organization.
example: We tagged former interns in our Talent pool so recruiters can easily re-engage them.

definition: A plan that defines where and how recruiters will search for suitable candidates for specific roles.
example: For senior engineers, the Sourcing strategy focuses on referrals and professional communities rather than job boards.

definition: Targeted hiring activities conducted at universities or colleges to attract graduates and interns.
example: Our Campus recruitment program includes case-study workshops and mock interviews.

definition: The practice of filling vacancies by moving existing employees across roles, teams, or locations.
example: Promoting Internal mobility increased retention among high-performing specialists.

definition: An internal request that formally initiates the hiring process for a specific position.
example: The hiring manager submitted a Job requisition outlining responsibilities and budget for the role.

definition: A deliberate approach to deciding where, when, and how to publish vacancy announcements.
example: We revised the Job posting strategy to prioritize niche platforms over generic job portals.

definition: How applicants perceive and emotionally respond to all interactions with an employer during the hiring journey.
example: Simplifying the application form significantly improved the overall Candidate experience.

definition: A staged view of the hiring pipeline that tracks how candidates move from attraction to offer acceptance.
example: By analyzing the Recruitment funnel, HR found that many applicants dropped out after the screening call.

definition: A metric that measures the number of days between opening a position and a candidate accepting the offer.
example: Reducing Time-to-hire by two weeks gave us an advantage in a competitive talent market.

definition: The average amount of money spent to fill a vacancy, including advertising, tools, and internal labor.
example: We calculated Cost-per-hire to justify investing in an in-house sourcing team.

definition: Software used to manage job applications, automate workflows, and store candidate data across the recruitment process.
example: Our Applicant tracking system automatically screens résumés for mandatory qualifications.

definition: A predefined inquiry used early in the hiring process to quickly eliminate candidates who do not meet basic criteria.
example: Adding a language proficiency Screening question saved recruiters hours of phone calls.

definition: A conversation in which all candidates are asked the same set of predefined, job-related questions.
example: Using a Structured interview format increased the consistency of our hiring decisions.

definition: An interview format that explores past behaviors to assess whether a candidate demonstrates specific job-related competencies.
example: In a Competency-based interview, candidates describe concrete situations instead of giving hypothetical answers.

definition: An interview style that focuses on how candidates handled real situations to predict future performance.
example: The recruiter used Behavioral interview questions to probe how the candidate manages conflict.

definition: A multi-step evaluation process that uses simulations, tests, and group exercises to assess candidates’ skills.
example: Graduates completed an Assessment center with role plays and case studies before receiving offers.

definition: The verification of a candidate’s identity, qualifications, and history before finalizing a hire.
example: Background screening revealed discrepancies in the candidate’s employment dates.

definition: The process of contacting previous supervisors or colleagues to validate a candidate’s experience and behavior.
example: A structured Reference check template helps managers ask consistent questions.

definition: Coordinating the content, approval, and communication of job offers to selected candidates.
example: Digital signatures made Offer management faster for both HR and candidates.

definition: A structured set of activities that help new employees integrate into the organization and become productive.
example: Our Onboarding program pairs every newcomer with a buddy during the first month.

definition: An initial phase of employment during which fit and performance are evaluated before confirming the contract.
example: The manager extended the Probation period to give the employee more time to improve.

definition: Introductory learning sessions that familiarize new employees with policies, tools, and culture.
example: All new hires attend Induction training on workplace ethics and safety rules.

definition: The set of formal and informal steps taken when an employee leaves the organization.
example: A well-designed Offboarding process protects knowledge and reduces legal risk.

definition: A structured conversation with a departing employee to collect feedback and understand the reasons for leaving.
example: Insights from the Exit interview led to improvements in our leadership training.

definition: A proactive approach to identifying and developing people who can step into key roles in the future.
example: Succession planning ensured there was a ready successor when the CFO retired.

definition: Designing and communicating possible role progressions that employees can follow within the organization.
example: Transparent Career pathing helped specialists see non-managerial growth options.

definition: A person identified as having the ability and motivation to grow into significantly larger roles.
example: High-potential employees receive accelerated development and stretch assignments.

definition: The flow of employees who are being prepared to assume leadership roles at different levels.
example: Gaps in the Leadership pipeline became visible when two directors left simultaneously.

definition: A personalized document that outlines an employee’s learning goals and actions over a defined period.
example: Every manager reviews the Individual development plan of their team members twice a year.

definition: A formal evaluation of an employee’s achievements and behaviors over a given timeframe.
example: The company replaced annual Performance appraisals with more frequent check-ins.

definition: The recurring schedule and steps used to plan, assess, and discuss employee performance.
example: Our Performance review cycle starts with goal-setting in January and ends with calibration in December.

definition: A documented agreement that sets expectations and support for an underperforming employee over a specific period.
example: The Performance improvement plan included clear targets and weekly coaching sessions.

definition: A goal-setting framework that links ambitious qualitative objectives with measurable outcomes.
example: The HR team uses Objectives and key results to align their projects with business priorities.

definition: A method where employees receive input on their behavior from managers, peers, direct reports, and sometimes customers.
example: Introducing 360-degree feedback exposed blind spots in how leaders communicated.

definition: A session in which managers compare performance ratings to ensure fairness and consistency across teams.
example: During the Calibration meeting, several ratings were adjusted for consistency.

definition: A function that designs and delivers learning solutions to build skills and support business strategy.
example: Investment in Learning and development grew as the company shifted to a digital model.

definition: A diagnostic process that identifies gaps between current and desired employee capabilities.
example: The Training needs analysis revealed a widespread lack of data literacy.

definition: A visual tool that maps employees’ competencies against the skills required for specific roles.
example: The Skills matrix helped allocate experts to critical project phases.

definition: The deliberate sharing of expertise from one person or group to others to reduce dependence on single experts.
example: Structured Knowledge transfer sessions were scheduled before the senior analyst retired.

definition: A development practice where employees temporarily move between different roles or departments.
example: Job rotation between sales and operations improved mutual understanding.

definition: Teaching employees to perform tasks outside their primary role to increase flexibility and resilience.
example: Cross-training the support team reduced service disruptions during absences.

definition: A structured initiative where experienced professionals guide and support the development of less experienced colleagues.
example: She credits her rapid promotion to the advice she received through the corporate Mentorship scheme.

definition: An environment in which leaders regularly use coaching behaviors to develop their teams.
example: Building a Coaching culture required training managers to ask more open questions.

definition: A structured meeting where leaders discuss the performance and potential of employees across the organization.
example: The annual Talent review highlighted a shortage of successors for technical leadership roles.

definition: The full portfolio of monetary and non-monetary benefits that employees receive from an employer.
example: The Total rewards strategy emphasizes wellbeing benefits instead of only higher pay.

definition: The guaranteed portion of an employee's compensation package, excluding variable bonuses and benefits.
example: While the Fixed remuneration was lower than average, the stock options made the offer attractive.

definition: The portion of compensation that depends on individual, team, or company performance.
example: For sales roles, Variable pay can make up half of the total compensation.

definition: A predefined range of salaries that applies to jobs of similar value or level.
example: Managers must keep offers within the Pay band approved for the role.

definition: A distinct level or grade within a compensation structure that dictates the minimum and maximum earnings for a role.
example: Moving to a management role usually places you in a significantly higher Pay bracket.

definition: A compensation level that groups roles with comparable responsibility and complexity.
example: Promotions often involve moving to a higher Pay grade with a different benefits package.

definition: A systematic method for determining the relative value of jobs to ensure internal pay fairness.
example: HR used a point-factor Job evaluation method before redesigning salary bands.

definition: The hierarchy of pay grades or levels that supports consistent compensation decisions.
example: The new Grading structure aligned managerial layers across all countries.

definition: Comparing internal pay levels with external market data to stay competitive and fair.
example: Annual Pay benchmarking showed that our engineers were paid below the market median.

definition: Setting salary levels for a role based mainly on external salary survey data.
example: For scarce skills, Market pricing is more influential than internal relativities.

definition: The principle that employees who contribute comparable value should receive comparable compensation.
example: The company launched a Pay equity review to address unexplained pay gaps.

definition: The degree to which an organization discloses information about pay structures and decisions.
example: Moving toward Pay transparency required training managers to explain salary rationales.

definition: A situation where pay differences between new hires and experienced employees become too small.
example: Rapid market increases caused Pay compression among software engineers.

definition: The pattern by which an employee’s pay moves within or across salary ranges over time.
example: Clear Pay progression guidelines reduce perceptions of favoritism.

definition: An increased pay rate applied to hours worked beyond the standard working time.
example: Warehouse staff receive an Overtime premium for night shifts.

definition: Additional compensation paid to employees who work less desirable hours or rotating shifts.
example: A Shift allowance helps attract nurses to weekend rotations.

definition: A one-time or temporary payment designed to encourage key employees to stay during critical periods.
example: Project leaders received a Retention bonus for staying until the system go-live.

definition: An unplanned, discretionary reward granted shortly after an exceptional contribution.
example: The manager gave a Spot bonus to the analyst who resolved a major client issue overnight.

definition: A scheme that links rewards to performance over several years, often using shares or deferred cash.
example: Executives participate in a Long-term incentive plan tied to sustainable profit growth.

definition: Income that is earned but paid at a later date, typically to encourage retention or support tax planning.
example: Part of the bonus was converted into Deferred compensation vested over three years.

definition: A program that gives employees the right to buy company shares at a predetermined price after a vesting period.
example: The Stock option plan aligns senior managers’ interests with those of shareholders.

definition: Forms of recognition that do not involve direct payments, such as development opportunities or extra time off.
example: Non-monetary rewards like special projects can be more motivating than cash for some employees.

definition: A structured approach for acknowledging and rewarding desired behaviors and achievements.
example: Our peer-nominated Recognition program increased cross-team collaboration.

definition: The collection of indirect rewards such as insurance, retirement plans, and perks offered by an employer.
example: Candidates often compare the Benefits package rather than just base pay.

definition: A system that allows employees to choose from a menu of benefit options within a fixed budget.
example: Through Flexible benefits, staff can swap gym passes for extra childcare support.

definition: A benefits arrangement where employees allocate credits or points to preferred options from a predefined list.
example: The Cafeteria plan lets employees trade part of their bonus for additional vacation days.

definition: A fixed budget that employees can spend on health-related goods or services.
example: Employees used the Wellness allowance for fitness classes and ergonomic equipment.

definition: A confidential support service that offers counseling and guidance on personal or work issues.
example: The Employee assistance program saw higher usage during the merger announcement.

definition: An arrangement through which employees accrue rights to receive income after retirement.
example: The company pension scheme matches employee contributions up to a fixed percentage.

definition: Compensation provided to employees when their employment is terminated under specified conditions.
example: Eligibility for Severance pay depends on length of service and local law.

definition: The combination of financial and non-financial terms offered to employees whose roles are eliminated.
example: The Redundancy package included outplacement services and extended health coverage.

definition: Support provided to departing employees to help them find new employment.
example: Outplacement services offered coaching on résumés and interview skills.

definition: A structured effort to move employees whose roles are at risk into open positions elsewhere in the organization.
example: The Redeployment program minimized compulsory layoffs during the reorganization.

definition: Financial support granted to employees who relocate or commute as part of their job.
example: A Mobility allowance made international assignments more attractive.

definition: A formal request submitted by an employee to be reimbursed for business-related costs paid from their own pocket.
example: You must attach all digital receipts to your Expense claim before the finance team approves it.

definition: The operational task of calculating wages, deductions, and net pay for employees.
example: Errors in Payroll processing can damage trust and create compliance risks.

definition: The review activity that checks payroll data against source records to ensure accuracy.
example: Monthly Payroll reconciliation compares paid amounts with approved timesheets.

definition: Systems and processes used to track hours worked, start and end times, and breaks for payroll purposes.
example: Modern Time and attendance software integrates directly with the payroll system to reduce errors.

definition: Coordinating policies, data, and interventions to handle employee time off effectively.
example: Better Absence management reduced unplanned sick days in customer service.

definition: The amount and type of time off an employee is legally or contractually allowed to take.
example: HR clarified Leave entitlement in a simple infographic for managers.

definition: Authorized time away from work granted to parents after the birth or adoption of a child.
example: The organization extended Parental leave to non-birth parents.

definition: The period of time an employee is away from work due to illness or injury, monitored for patterns.
example: Frequent short-term Sickness absence triggered a formal review by the line manager.

definition: Guidelines that regulate working from locations other than the employer’s premises.
example: The Remote work policy specifies eligibility, equipment, and data security requirements.

definition: An arrangement in which employees split their working time between remote and on-site locations.
example: The Hybrid work model is designed around team agreements, not individual preferences alone.

definition: A scheduling arrangement that allows employees to choose their starting and ending times within agreed limits.
example: Flextime has significantly reduced tardiness during the morning rush hour.

definition: A program aimed at helping employees manage professional and personal responsibilities sustainably.
example: The Work-life balance initiative promoted meeting-free time blocks in the calendar.

definition: The set of practices, policies, and controls that prevent work-related injuries and illnesses.
example: Occupational health and safety training is mandatory for all line managers.

definition: A short meeting held after an absence to discuss reasons for leave and any support needed.
example: Supervisors conduct a Return-to-work interview after every extended sick leave.

definition: Adjustments to a job or workplace that enable someone with specific needs to perform essential duties.
example: Providing assistive technology counted as a Reasonable accommodation for the employee.

definition: Authorized time away from work granted due to a health condition that limits work capacity.
example: Clear rules around Disability leave reduce anxiety for employees facing serious illness.

definition: The emotional and cognitive connection employees feel toward their work and organization.
example: High Employee engagement often correlates with better customer satisfaction scores.

definition: A structured questionnaire that measures how committed and energized employees feel.
example: The Engagement survey highlighted concerns about workload and recognition.

definition: Employees’ shared perceptions of policies, practices, and routines at a given point in time.
example: A trust deficit in leadership negatively influenced the Organizational climate.

definition: The underlying values, norms, and behaviors that shape how work gets done in an organization.
example: Mergers often fail when Organizational cultures are incompatible.

definition: A shared belief that the team is safe for interpersonal risk-taking, such as asking questions or admitting mistakes.
example: Teams with strong Psychological safety report more errors but learn from them faster.

definition: The voluntary promotion of an employer’s brand and values by its employees.
example: Social media guidelines encourage authentic Employee advocacy.

definition: A formal channel through which employees can express opinions, suggestions, or concerns.
example: Anonymous hotlines are one type of Employee voice mechanism.

definition: A documented process that employees can follow to raise and resolve complaints.
example: Trade unions negotiated changes to the Grievance procedure after a high-profile case.

definition: A formal response to misconduct or performance issues that can range from warnings to dismissal.
example: Managers must document every Disciplinary action in the HR system.

definition: An approach that applies increasingly serious consequences if an issue is not corrected.
example: The company uses Progressive discipline to give employees a chance to improve.

definition: Rules that define unacceptable behavior and outline how reports of harassment are handled.
example: Mandatory training explains the Harassment policy with real-life examples.

definition: A commitment that employees who report concerns in good faith will not suffer negative consequences.
example: The Anti-retaliation policy is mentioned in every whistleblowing communication.

definition: Guidelines that describe how employees can safely report suspected wrongdoing.
example: An external hotline supports the Whistleblowing policy for sensitive cases.

definition: A formal document that sets expectations for ethical and professional behavior.
example: Violations of the Code of conduct can lead to disciplinary measures.

definition: A voluntary process in which a neutral third party helps employees resolve conflicts.
example: Workplace mediation prevented a long-running dispute from escalating.

definition: Learning interventions that build skills for managing disagreements constructively.
example: Supervisors attend Conflict resolution training as part of leadership development.

definition: Negotiations between employers and employee representatives over pay and working conditions.
example: Collective bargaining rounds are scheduled every two years in the sector.

definition: An elected body representing employees in consultations on workplace issues.
example: The Works council must be informed before major reorganizations.

definition: A group formally authorized to speak on behalf of employees in discussions with management.
example: The Employee representative body reviewed the proposed shift schedule changes.

definition: A formal document in which an employer accepts a trade union as the bargaining agent.
example: The Union recognition agreement specifies which employees are covered.

definition: The range of differences among people in an organization, including background, identity, and perspectives.
example: Workforce diversity can improve problem-solving by bringing in varied viewpoints.

definition: A long-term plan for building a more representative workforce and inclusive environment.
example: Targets for leadership representation are part of the Diversity and inclusion strategy.

definition: The examination of pay data to identify unexplained differences between groups, such as genders or age bands.
example: Annual Pay gap analysis informs corrective pay adjustments and policy changes.

definition: Disclosing statistics that compare average earnings of women and men in an organization.
example: Regulatory Gender pay gap reporting increases pressure to address structural imbalances.

definition: A statement that commits the employer to non-discrimination in recruitment and employment decisions.
example: Job adverts are reviewed to ensure they align with the Equal opportunities policy.

definition: HR practices that address the needs and strengths of employees at different life stages.
example: Age management initiatives include phased retirement and intergenerational mentoring.

definition: Programs that help leaders recognize bias and create more inclusive team practices.
example: Inclusive leadership training is mandatory for all people managers.

definition: The use of data and statistical methods to understand and improve workforce decisions.
example: Talent analytics helped predict which roles had the highest risk of resignation.

definition: A broader discipline that combines HR data with business metrics to generate insights about human capital.
example: People analytics linked engagement scores with customer churn in specific regions.

definition: A visual display of key HR metrics that supports regular monitoring and decision-making.
example: The HR dashboard shows headcount, turnover, and internal mobility trends by segment.

definition: The calculation of the total workforce workload converted into the equivalent number of full-time employees.
example: The FTE analysis showed we are understaffed despite the high number of part-time workers.

definition: Dividing employees into groups based on shared characteristics to tailor HR practices.
example: Workforce segmentation distinguished critical experts from easily replaceable roles.

definition: A position whose vacancy would create disproportionate risk for the organization.
example: Succession plans prioritize every identified Critical role.

definition: The number of direct reports that a manager supervises.
example: Very wide Span of control can limit the quality of coaching a manager can provide.

definition: Deliberately changing structures, roles, and reporting lines to better support strategy.
example: Organizational redesign moved HR business partners closer to product teams.

definition: A roadmap of communications, training, and support actions that guide people through a transition.
example: The Change management plan identified key stakeholders and resistance points.

definition: A group of employees who promote and support a transformation within their local teams.
example: The Change champion network gathered feedback from frontline staff during the rollout.

definition: An HR professional who works closely with a specific part of the business to align people practices with strategy.
example: The HR business partner joined leadership meetings to anticipate talent needs.

definition: A centralized unit that delivers standardized HR transactions and support to multiple parts of the organization.
example: Creating HR shared services reduced duplication across country teams.

definition: A documented list of HR services, with descriptions and service levels, available to managers and employees.
example: The HR service catalogue clarifies who to contact for payroll versus benefits questions.

definition: A specialized team within HR that provides deep knowledge in areas like compensation or talent analytics.
example: The Center of expertise for rewards designed the new equity plan.

definition: A strategic plan that outlines the future implementation and integration of HR systems.
example: Our HR technology roadmap prioritizes a new learning platform and analytics tools.

definition: A specialist who manages and configures the Human Resources Information System.
example: The HRIS analyst is responsible for creating new reports and ensuring data integrity.

definition: A web-based tool that allows employees to manage their own personal data, leave, and benefits.
example: Updating your address is easy using the Employee self-service portal.

definition: A feature in HR systems that enables managers to perform tasks like approving leave or initiating hires.
example: Implementing Manager self-service reduced the administrative burden on the HR department.

definition: Ensuring that HR practices for collecting and storing employee information adhere to legal requirements.
example: Data privacy compliance became a top priority with the introduction of new regulations.

definition: A systematic review of HR policies, procedures, and practices to assess compliance and effectiveness.
example: An internal HR audit revealed inconsistencies in our hiring documentation.

definition: A framework that governs the terms and conditions for employees who are transferred internationally.
example: The Global mobility policy covers everything from tax support to cultural training.

definition: A temporary posting of an employee to work in a foreign country.
example: The engineer was offered a three-year Expatriate assignment in the new research center.

definition: The set of actions that support an employee's return to their home country after an international assignment.
example: A well-managed Repatriation process helps retain valuable experience gained abroad.
